bone_facts.Right_upper_canine_tooth: Also known as a cuspid, this pointed tooth is located at the corner of the dental arch and is primarily used for tearing and gripping food.
bone_facts.Left_eleventh_rib: This is a 'floating rib' because it does not connect to the sternum or costal cartilage. It provides protection for the posterior organs, such as the kidney.
bone_facts.Left_twelfth_rib: Like the eleventh rib, this is a 'floating rib' that does not attach to the sternum. It is often the shortest of all the ribs.
bone_facts.Left_first_rib: The first rib is the shortest, broadest, and most curved rib. It has grooves on its superior surface for the subclavian artery and vein to pass over.
bone_facts.Left_second_rib: This rib is significantly longer than the first and provides an attachment point for the serratus anterior and posterior scalene muscles.
bone_facts.Left_third_rib: This is a 'true rib,' meaning it connects directly to the sternum via its own costal cartilage. It helps form the protective thoracic cage.
bone_facts.Left_fourth_rib: A 'true rib' that articulates with the sternum, contributing to the structure and integrity of the upper chest wall.
bone_facts.Left_fifth_rib: This 'true rib' connects directly to the body of the sternum and serves as an important landmark for auscultation of the heart and lungs.
bone_facts.Left_sixth_rib: As one of the 'true ribs,' it connects directly to the sternum, providing robust protection for the heart and lungs.
bone_facts.Left_seventh_rib: This is the last and longest of the 'true ribs.' Its costal cartilage attaches directly to the sternum, marking the lower border of the main thoracic cage.
bone_facts.Left_eighth_rib: This is the first of the 'false ribs,' as its costal cartilage connects to the cartilage of the seventh rib above it, not directly to the sternum.
bone_facts.Left_ninth_rib: A 'false rib' whose costal cartilage joins the cartilage of the rib above, contributing to the costal margin of the rib cage.
bone_facts.Left_clavicle: Commonly known as the collarbone, it acts as a strut connecting the sternum to the scapula, supporting the shoulder and allowing for a wide range of arm motion.
bone_facts.Left_first_costal_cartilage: This is a short, thick bar of hyaline cartilage that connects the first rib to the manubrium of the sternum, forming a very strong, inflexible joint.
bone_facts.Left_first_metacarpal_bone: This bone forms the base of the thumb. Its unique saddle-shaped joint with the trapezium allows the thumb to be opposable.
bone_facts.Left_first_metatarsal_bone: The shortest and thickest of the metatarsal bones, it is crucial for supporting weight and propulsion during walking and running.
bone_facts.Left_second_costal_cartilage: This cartilage connects the second rib to the sternum at the sternal angle, an important anatomical landmark.
bone_facts.Left_second_metacarpal_bone: This is the longest metacarpal bone and articulates with the trapezoid, trapezium, and capitate bones in the wrist.
bone_facts.Left_second_metatarsal_bone: This is the longest metatarsal bone, securely wedged between the cuneiform bones, which provides stability to the foot's transverse arch.
bone_facts.Left_third_costal_cartilage: A bar of hyaline cartilage connecting the third rib to the body of the sternum, contributing to the elasticity of the chest wall.
bone_facts.Left_third_metacarpal_bone: The metacarpal of the middle finger, which articulates with the capitate bone of the wrist.
bone_facts.Left_third_metatarsal_bone: This metatarsal connects the third toe to the tarsal bones and helps maintain the arch of the foot.
bone_facts.Left_fourth_costal_cartilage: Connects the fourth rib to the sternum, allowing for the slight movement necessary for breathing.
bone_facts.Left_fourth_metacarpal_bone: The metacarpal of the ring finger, articulating with the capitate and hamate bones.
bone_facts.Left_fourth_metatarsal_bone: A bone of the midfoot that helps distribute weight across the foot during movement.
bone_facts.Left_fifth_costal_cartilage: Connects the fifth rib to the sternum, contributing to the formation of the lower part of the thoracic cage.
bone_facts.Left_fifth_metacarpal_bone: The metacarpal of the little finger. It is the most mobile of the metacarpals, except for the first (thumb).
bone_facts.Left_fifth_metatarsal_bone: Located on the outer edge of the foot, this bone has a prominent tuberosity that is a common site for fractures.
bone_facts.Left_sixth_costal_cartilage: Connects the sixth rib to the sternum, helping to provide both protection and flexibility to the chest.
bone_facts.Left_seventh_costal_cartilage: This is the longest costal cartilage and the last one to directly attach to the sternum.
bone_facts.Left_calcaneus: Commonly known as the heel bone, it is the largest of the tarsal bones in the foot and is the first bone to contact the ground during a normal walking gait.
bone_facts.Left_capitate: The largest of the carpal (wrist) bones, located in the center of the wrist. Its name means 'head-shaped.'
bone_facts.Left_cuboid_bone: A cube-shaped bone on the outer side of the foot that provides stability and helps form the foot's lateral arch.
bone_facts.Left_femur: The thigh bone, which is the longest, heaviest, and strongest bone in the human body.
bone_facts.Left_fibula: The slender bone located on the lateral side of the lower leg, parallel to the tibia. It primarily serves as an attachment point for muscles rather than for weight-bearing.
bone_facts.Left_hamate: A wedge-shaped carpal (wrist) bone that is distinguished by a hook-like process called the hamulus.
bone_facts.Left_humerus: The long bone of the upper arm, running from the shoulder to the elbow. Hitting the ulnar nerve against this bone creates the 'funny bone' sensation.
bone_facts.Left_inferior_nasal_concha: A scroll-shaped bone on the sidewall of the nasal cavity. It helps to filter, warm, and humidify inhaled air.
bone_facts.Left_intermediate_cuneiform_bone: The smallest of the three cuneiform bones in the foot, located between the medial and lateral cuneiforms.
bone_facts.Left_lacrimal_bone: A small, thin bone located at the front part of the medial wall of the orbit (eye socket). It is the smallest bone in the face.
bone_facts.Sesamoid_bone_of_left_foot: A small, independent bone embedded in a tendon, typically near the joint of the big toe. It helps to protect the tendon and improve its mechanical advantage.
bone_facts.Left_lateral_cuneiform_bone: A wedge-shaped tarsal bone in the foot that articulates with the cuboid and several metatarsals, contributing to the transverse arch.
bone_facts.Left_lunate: A crescent-shaped carpal (wrist) bone located centrally. It is the most frequently dislocated carpal bone.
bone_facts.Left_maxilla: This bone forms the upper jaw and holds the upper teeth. It also forms parts of the orbit, nasal cavity, and the roof of the mouth.
bone_facts.Left_medial_cuneiform_bone: The largest of the three cuneiform bones in the foot, it articulates with the navicular and the first metatarsal.
bone_facts.Left_palatine_bone: An L-shaped bone located at the back of the nasal cavity that forms the posterior part of the hard palate (roof of the mouth).
bone_facts.Left_parietal_bone: This bone forms a large part of the side and roof of the cranium. The two parietal bones are joined together at the sagittal suture.
bone_facts.Left_patella: Commonly known as the kneecap, it is the largest sesamoid bone in the body and protects the knee joint.
bone_facts.Left_pisiform: A small, pea-shaped sesamoid bone in the wrist, located where the ulna joins the wrist. It is the last carpal bone to ossify.
bone_facts.Left_radius: One of the two bones of the forearm, located on the thumb side. It pivots around the ulna to allow the hand to rotate.
bone_facts.Left_scaphoid: A boat-shaped carpal bone located on the thumb side of the wrist. It is the most commonly fractured carpal bone.
bone_facts.Left_scapula: Commonly known as the shoulder blade, this large triangular bone connects the humerus (upper arm bone) with the clavicle (collarbone).
bone_facts.Left_talus: A key ankle bone that sits above the calcaneus (heel bone). Uniquely, it has no muscles attached directly to it.
bone_facts.Left_temporal_bone: This bone is located at the sides and base of the skull. It houses the structures of the ear.
bone_facts.Left_tibia: The larger of the two bones in the lower leg, commonly known as the shin bone. It is the main weight-bearing bone of the lower leg.
bone_facts.Left_trapezium: A four-sided carpal bone on the thumb side of the wrist. It forms the critical saddle-shaped joint with the first metacarpal.
bone_facts.Left_trapezoid: The smallest carpal bone in the distal row of the wrist, articulating primarily with the second metacarpal.
bone_facts.Left_triquetral: A pyramidal-shaped carpal bone on the ulnar (little finger) side of the wrist.
bone_facts.Left_ulna: One of two bones in the forearm, located on the little finger side. Its upper end forms the bony point of the elbow.
bone_facts.Right_trapezoid: The smallest carpal bone in the distal row of the right wrist, articulating with the second metacarpal.
bone_facts.Hyoid_bone: A unique U-shaped bone located in the anterior neck. It is the only bone in the human body that does not articulate with any other bone.
bone_facts.Right_hip_bone: Also known as the os coxa or innominate bone, it is formed by the fusion of three bones: the ilium, ischium, and pubis. It connects the axial skeleton to the lower limb.
bone_facts.Xiphoid_process: The small, cartilaginous lower tip of the sternum. It slowly ossifies (turns to bone) during adulthood.
bone_facts.Tenth_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra is a transition point, often having a facet pattern that shares characteristics with both typical thoracic and lumbar vertebrae.
bone_facts.Eleventh_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra articulates with the eleventh (floating) rib and begins the transition to the lumbar spine, lacking facets for the rib tubercle.
bone_facts.Twelfth_thoracic_vertebra: This is the last thoracic vertebra and has characteristics of a lumbar vertebra, supporting more weight and articulating with the last floating rib.
bone_facts.First_lumbar_vertebra: The first of the five large, robust vertebrae in the lower back that are designed to support the weight of the upper body.
bone_facts.First_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra is unique as it articulates with the first rib and has features similar to a cervical vertebra.
bone_facts.Second_lumbar_vertebra: A large vertebra in the lower back that provides support and flexibility. The spinal cord typically ends near this vertebral level.
bone_facts.Second_thoracic_vertebra: A typical thoracic vertebra that provides attachment points for the second pair of ribs.
bone_facts.Third_cervical_vertebra: A typical cervical vertebra in the neck, characterized by a small body and a bifid (split) spinous process.
bone_facts.Third_lumbar_vertebra: Located in the small of the back, this vertebra is designed for powerful weight-bearing and flexion/extension movements.
bone_facts.Third_thoracic_vertebra: Provides articulation for the third pair of ribs and contributes to the kyphotic (outward) curve of the upper spine.
bone_facts.Fourth_cervical_vertebra: A vertebra in the neck that helps support the head and allows for its movement.
bone_facts.Fourth_lumbar_vertebra: A large, weight-bearing vertebra in the lower back. The space between L4 and L5 is a common site for disk herniation.
bone_facts.Fourth_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra articulates with the fourth pair of ribs and helps protect the spinal cord.
bone_facts.Fifth_cervical_vertebra: A neck vertebra that is part of the cervical curve, allowing for flexibility and support of the head.
bone_facts.Fifth_lumbar_vertebra: The largest of all vertebrae in the spinal column. It bears the most weight and is a common source of back problems.
bone_facts.Fifth_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra connects to the fifth pair of ribs and is part of the rigid thoracic spine that protects vital organs.
bone_facts.Sixth_cervical_vertebra: This neck vertebra has a prominent anterior tubercle known as the carotid tubercle.
bone_facts.Sixth_thoracic_vertebra: Articulates with the sixth pair of ribs and contributes to the protective cage around the heart and lungs.
bone_facts.Seventh_cervical_vertebra: Known as the 'vertebra prominens' because its long spinous process is easily felt at the base of the neck.
bone_facts.Seventh_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra provides an articulation point for the seventh pair of ribs, the last of the 'true ribs'.
bone_facts.Eighth_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra articulates with the eighth pair of ribs, which are considered 'false ribs'.
bone_facts.Ninth_thoracic_vertebra: This vertebra connects to the ninth pair of 'false ribs,' helping to form the costal margin.
bone_facts.Atlas: The first cervical vertebra (C1), which supports the globe of the head. It is unique in that it has no vertebral body and allows for the 'yes' nodding motion of the head.
bone_facts.Axis: The second cervical vertebra (C2), distinguished by a large bony projection called the dens, which acts as a pivot point for the atlas, allowing for the 'no' side-to-side rotation of the head.
bone_facts.Body_of_sternum: The longest part of the sternum (breastbone), it articulates with the costal cartilages of ribs 2 through 7.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_second_toe: The outermost bone of the second toe, supporting the toenail bed.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_third_toe: The bone at the very tip of the third toe.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_fourth_toe: The tip bone of the fourth toe, which is often very small.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_big_toe: The bone at the tip of the great toe. It is broader and flatter than the other toe phalanges.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_index_finger: The bone at the tip of the index finger, which provides support for the nail and the sensitive fingertip pulp.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_little_finger: The smallest and most delicate of the distal phalanges in the hand, located at the tip of the little finger.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_little_toe: The bone at the tip of the smallest toe.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_middle_finger: The bone at the tip of the middle finger, crucial for fine motor skills and grip.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_ring_finger: The outermost bone of the ring finger.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_left_thumb: The single bone at the tip of the thumb, which is broader than those of the other fingers.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_second_toe: The bone at the tip of the second toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_third_toe: The outermost bone of the third toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_fourth_toe: The small bone at the tip of the fourth toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_big_toe: The bone at the tip of the right great toe, essential for the 'push-off' phase of walking.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_index_finger: The tip bone of the right index finger, crucial for dexterity.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_little_finger: The bone at the tip of the little finger on the right hand.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_little_toe: The outermost bone of the little toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_middle_finger: The bone forming the tip of the middle finger on the right hand.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_ring_finger: The tip bone of the ring finger on the right hand.
bone_facts.Distal_phalanx_of_right_thumb: The bone at the tip of the right thumb, providing broad support for the nail.
bone_facts.Frontal_bone: This bone forms the forehead and the upper part of the eye sockets. In infants, it starts as two separate bones that later fuse together.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_axis: There is no intervertebral disk between the atlas (C1) and axis (C2); their articulation is a unique pivot joint.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_fourth_thoracic_v: A fibrocartilage cushion located between the fourth and fifth thoracic vertebrae, acting as a shock absorber.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_fifth_thoracic_ve: The shock-absorbing disk situated between the fifth and sixth thoracic vertebrae.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_sixth_thoracic_ve: The fibrocartilaginous joint located between the sixth and seventh thoracic vertebrae.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_seventh_thoracic_: The cushion between the seventh and eighth thoracic vertebrae, allowing for slight movement.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_eighth_thoracic_v: The disk between the eighth and ninth thoracic vertebrae, contributing to the spine's flexibility.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_ninth_thoracic_ve: A pad of fibrocartilage that separates the ninth and tenth thoracic vertebrae.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_tenth_thoracic_ve: The shock absorber between the tenth and eleventh thoracic vertebrae.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_eleventh_thoracic: The disk between the eleventh and twelfth thoracic vertebrae, which is thicker than those above it.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_twelfth_thoracic_: The last thoracic intervertebral disk, located between T12 and L1, marking the transition to the more mobile lumbar spine.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_first_lumbar_vert: A thick, strong disk between L1 and L2 designed to withstand significant compressive forces.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_third_cervical_ve: The fibrocartilage pad between the C3 and C4 vertebrae in the neck, allowing for flexibility.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_second_lumbar_ver: The cushion between the second and third lumbar vertebrae, crucial for lower back mobility.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_third_lumbar_vert: The disk between L3 and L4, which helps absorb the stress of lifting and movement.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_fourth_lumbar_ver: Located between L4 and L5, this is one of the most common sites for disk herniation due to high mechanical stress.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_fifth_lumbar_vert: The last intervertebral disk, located between L5 and the sacrum. It is wedge-shaped to help form the lumbosacral angle.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_fourth_cervical_v: The disk between the C4 and C5 vertebrae, providing cushioning in the neck.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_fifth_cervical_ve: A disk between C5 and C6 that is frequently affected by degenerative changes due to high neck mobility.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_sixth_cervical_ve: The pad between C6 and C7, another common site for cervical spine issues.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_seventh_cervical_: The last cervical disk, located between C7 and T1, marking the transition from the flexible neck to the rigid upper back.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_first_thoracic_ve: The cushion between the first and second thoracic vertebrae.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_second_thoracic_v: The fibrocartilage pad separating the second and third thoracic vertebrae.
bone_facts.Intervertebral_disk_of_third_thoracic_ve: The shock absorber between the third and fourth thoracic vertebrae.
bone_facts.Left_tenth_rib: The last of the 'false ribs,' its cartilage connects to the cartilage of the rib above it to form the costal margin.
bone_facts.Left_zygomatic_bone: Commonly known as the cheekbone, it forms the prominence of the cheek and part of the orbit's side and floor.
bone_facts.Left_hip_bone: Also called the os coxa, this large, irregular bone is formed by the fusion of the ilium, ischium, and pubis and connects the spine to the lower limb.
bone_facts.Mandible: The lower jawbone. It is the largest, strongest, and only movable bone in the skull (excluding the ear ossicles).
bone_facts.Manubrium: The broad, upper part of the sternum (breastbone). It articulates with the clavicles and the first two pairs of ribs.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_ring_finger: The bone in the middle segment of the ring finger, located between the proximal and distal phalanges.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_ring_finger: The middle bone of the right ring finger.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_second_toe: The middle bone of the second toe. Some people lack this bone in their smaller toes.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_third_toe: The bone in the middle of the third toe.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_fourth_toe: The middle bone of the fourth toe, which is often fused with the distal phalanx.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_index_finger: The middle bone of the index finger, essential for forming a grip.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_little_finger: The middle bone of the little finger.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_little_toe: This bone is frequently absent, with the proximal and distal phalanges of the little toe being fused.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_left_middle_finger: The middle bone of the middle finger.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_second_toe: The middle bone of the second toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_third_toe: The middle bone of the third toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_fourth_toe: The middle bone of the fourth toe on the right foot, which may be fused to the distal phalanx.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_index_finger: The middle bone of the right index finger.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_little_finger: The middle bone of the little finger on the right hand.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_little_toe: The middle bone of the little toe on the right foot; it is often congenitally fused with the distal phalanx.
bone_facts.Middle_phalanx_of_right_middle_finger: The middle bone of the middle finger on the right hand.
bone_facts.Navicular_bone_of_left_foot: A boat-shaped bone in the foot that articulates with the talus and the three cuneiform bones. It is a key component of the foot's medial longitudinal arch.
bone_facts.Navicular_bone_of_right_foot: The boat-shaped tarsal bone in the right foot, crucial for maintaining the arch.
bone_facts.Occipital_bone: This bone forms the back and base of the skull. It contains a large opening called the foramen magnum, which allows the spinal cord to connect to the brain.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_big_toe: The bone of the great toe that is closest to the foot. It is larger and stronger than the other proximal phalanges of the toes.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_third_toe: The bone of the third toe that is closest to the main body of the foot.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_fourth_toe: The first bone of the fourth toe, articulating with the fourth metatarsal.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_index_finger: The first bone of the index finger, articulating with the second metacarpal at the knuckle.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_little_finger: The bone of the little finger closest to the palm.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_little_toe: The first bone of the little toe.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_middle_finger: The first bone of the middle finger, forming the base of the finger at the knuckle.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_ring_finger: The bone of the ring finger closest to the palm.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_thumb: The first and only proximal phalanx of the thumb, articulating with the first metacarpal.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_second_toe: The bone of the second toe closest to the body of the right foot.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_third_toe: The first bone of the third toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_fourth_toe: The bone of the fourth toe on the right foot that articulates with the metatarsals.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_index_finger: The first bone of the right index finger.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_little_finger: The bone of the little finger on the right hand that is closest to the palm.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_little_toe: The first bone of the little toe on the right foot.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_middle_finger: The first bone of the middle finger on the right hand.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_ring_finger: The bone of the right ring finger closest to the knuckle.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_right_thumb: The first bone of the right thumb.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_second_toe: The bone of the second toe that is closest to the foot's arch.
bone_facts.Proximal_phalanx_of_left_big_toe: The bone of the great toe that connects to the first metatarsal, forming the main joint for pushing off during walking.
bone_facts.Right_tenth_rib: A 'false rib' on the right side, its cartilage attaches to the cartilage of the rib cage above it.
bone_facts.Right_eleventh_rib: A 'floating rib' on the right side that helps protect the right kidney.
bone_facts.Right_twelfth_rib: The shortest 'floating rib' on the right side, serving as an attachment point for the diaphragm.
bone_facts.Right_first_costal_cartilage: The strong cartilage connecting the first rib to the manubrium on the right side.
bone_facts.Right_first_rib: The shortest and most curved rib on the right side of the thoracic cage.
bone_facts.Right_second_costal_cartilage: The cartilage connecting the second rib to the right side of the sternum.
bone_facts.Right_second_rib: The second rib on the right side, which helps protect the upper thoracic organs.
bone_facts.Right_third_costal_cartilage: Connects the third rib directly to the right side of the sternum.
bone_facts.Right_third_rib: A 'true rib' on the right side of the chest.
bone_facts.Right_fourth_costal_cartilage: The cartilage attaching the fourth rib to the right side of the sternum.
bone_facts.Right_fourth_rib: A 'true rib' on the right, contributing to the protective thoracic cage.
bone_facts.Right_fifth_costal_cartilage: Connects the fifth rib to the body of the sternum on the right side.
bone_facts.Right_fifth_rib: A 'true rib' on the right side of the body.
bone_facts.Right_sixth_costal_cartilage: The bar of cartilage that connects the sixth rib to the right side of the sternum.
bone_facts.Right_sixth_rib: A 'true rib' on the right, providing thoracic protection.
bone_facts.Right_seventh_costal_cartilage: The last and longest costal cartilage to directly attach to the sternum on the right side.
bone_facts.Right_seventh_rib: The last 'true rib' on the right side.
bone_facts.Right_eighth_rib: The first 'false rib' on the right side.
bone_facts.Right_ninth_rib: A 'false rib' on the right, joining the costal cartilage above it.
bone_facts.Right_radius: The bone in the right forearm on the thumb side, which allows for rotation of the hand.
bone_facts.Right_first_metacarpal_bone: The bone at the base of the right thumb, crucial for grip and dexterity.
bone_facts.Right_first_metatarsal_bone: The thick bone connecting the right big toe to the tarsals, essential for propulsion.
bone_facts.Right_second_metacarpal_bone: The longest metacarpal in the right hand, providing stability.
bone_facts.Right_second_metatarsal_bone: The longest metatarsal in the right foot, locking into the cuneiforms to stabilize the arch.
bone_facts.Right_third_metacarpal_bone: The metacarpal of the right middle finger.
bone_facts.Right_third_metatarsal_bone: The metatarsal supporting the third toe of the right foot.
bone_facts.Right_fourth_metacarpal_bone: The metacarpal of the right ring finger.
bone_facts.Right_fourth_metatarsal_bone: The metatarsal supporting the fourth toe of the right foot.
bone_facts.Right_fifth_metacarpal_bone: The metacarpal of the right little finger.
bone_facts.Right_fifth_metatarsal_bone: The outermost metatarsal of the right foot, a common site for stress fractures.
bone_facts.Right_calcaneus: The heel bone of the right foot, the largest bone in the foot.
bone_facts.Right_capitate: The largest carpal bone in the center of the right wrist.
bone_facts.Right_clavicle: The collarbone on the right side, connecting the sternum to the right shoulder.
bone_facts.Right_cuboid_bone: The cube-shaped bone on the outside of the right foot.
bone_facts.Right_femur: The thigh bone of the right leg, the longest and strongest bone in the body.
bone_facts.Right_fibula: The thinner, lateral bone of the right lower leg.
bone_facts.Right_hamate: The wedge-shaped carpal bone in the right wrist with a distinctive hook.
bone_facts.Right_humerus: The bone of the right upper arm.
bone_facts.Right_inferior_nasal_concha: The scroll-like bone in the right nasal passage that helps warm and humidify air.
bone_facts.Right_intermediate_cuneiform_bone: The smallest of the three cuneiform bones in the right foot.
bone_facts.Right_lacrimal_bone: The small bone in the inner wall of the right eye socket.
bone_facts.Right_lateral_cuneiform_bone: The outer of the three wedge-shaped cuneiform bones in the right foot.
bone_facts.Right_lunate: The crescent-shaped carpal bone in the right wrist.
bone_facts.Right_maxilla: The bone forming the right side of the upper jaw.
bone_facts.Right_medial_cuneiform_bone: The largest of the three cuneiform bones in the right foot, articulating with the big toe's metatarsal.
bone_facts.Right_palatine_bone: The L-shaped bone forming the back part of the roof of the mouth on the right side.
bone_facts.Right_parietal_bone: The bone forming the upper right side of the cranium.
bone_facts.Right_patella: The kneecap of the right knee.
bone_facts.Right_pisiform: The small, pea-shaped sesamoid bone in the right wrist.
bone_facts.Right_scaphoid: The boat-shaped carpal bone on the thumb side of the right wrist, frequently fractured in falls.
bone_facts.Right_scapula: The shoulder blade on the right side.
bone_facts.Right_talus: The ankle bone in the right foot that articulates with the tibia and fibula.
bone_facts.Right_temporal_bone: The bone at the right side and base of the skull, containing the ear structures.
bone_facts.Right_tibia: The shin bone of the right leg, the primary weight-bearing bone.
bone_facts.Right_trapezium: The carpal bone of the right wrist that forms the saddle joint with the thumb's metacarpal.
bone_facts.Right_triquetral: The pyramidal-shaped carpal bone on the little-finger side of the right wrist.
bone_facts.Right_ulna: The forearm bone on the little-finger side of the right arm.
bone_facts.Right_zygomatic_bone: The cheekbone on the right side of the face.
bone_facts.Sacrum: A large, triangular bone at the base of the spine, formed by the fusion of five vertebrae. It forms the back wall of the pelvis.
bone_facts.Sphenoid_bone: A complex, butterfly-shaped bone at the base of the skull that articulates with almost every other bone of the skull.
bone_facts.Left_tenth_costal_cartilage: The cartilage of the tenth rib, which attaches to the cartilage of the rib above it rather than the sternum.
bone_facts.Right_tenth_costal_cartilage: The cartilage connecting the tenth rib on the right side to the costal margin.
bone_facts.Left_eighth_costal_cartilage: The cartilage connecting the eighth rib to the cartilage of the seventh rib on the left side.
bone_facts.Right_eighth_costal_cartilage: The cartilage of the eighth rib on the right side, which helps form the costal margin.
bone_facts.Left_ninth_costal_cartilage: The cartilage of the ninth rib on the left side.
bone_facts.Right_ninth_costal_cartilage: The cartilage of the ninth rib on the right side.
bone_facts.Ethmoid: A spongy, cube-shaped bone located at the roof of the nose. It forms part of the cranial floor, orbits, and nasal cavity, and it contains sinuses.
bone_facts.Left_nasal_bone: One of two small bones that meet at the midline to form the bridge of the nose.
bone_facts.Perpendicular_plate_of_ethmoid: A thin, flat plate of the ethmoid bone that descends from the crista galli and forms the upper part of the nasal septum.
bone_facts.Right_nasal_bone: The small oblong bone on the right side that forms the bridge of the nose.
bone_facts.Vomer: A thin, flat bone that forms the inferior and posterior part of the nasal septum, dividing the nasal cavity into left and right sides.
bone_facts.Left_stylomandibular_ligament: A ligament that runs from the styloid process to the angle of the mandible, limiting excessive opening and protrusion of the jaw.
bone_facts.Right_stylomandibular_ligament: The ligament on the right side that limits the movement of the mandible.
bone_facts.Left_first_lower_molar_tooth: The largest tooth in the lower jaw, with multiple cusps designed for grinding and crushing food.
bone_facts.Left_first_lower_premolar_tooth: A transitional tooth between the canine and molar, used for both tearing and grinding.
bone_facts.Left_second_lower_molar_tooth: A large tooth in the back of the lower jaw, used for grinding food.
bone_facts.Left_second_lower_premolar_tooth: The tooth located between the first premolar and first molar, assisting in grinding.
bone_facts.Left_lower_central_incisor_tooth: The smallest of all teeth, located at the front of the lower jaw, used for cutting and shearing food.
bone_facts.Left_lower_lateral_incisor_tooth: Located next to the central incisor, it is slightly larger and helps in cutting food.
bone_facts.Left_lower_canine_tooth: The pointed 'cornerstone' tooth in the lower jaw used for tearing food.
bone_facts.Left_first_upper_molar_tooth: A large, strong tooth in the upper jaw with a complex cusp pattern for efficient grinding.
bone_facts.Left_first_upper_premolar_tooth: Also known as a bicuspid, this tooth has two cusps and is used for tearing and grinding.
bone_facts.Left_second_upper_molar_tooth: A posterior tooth in the upper jaw used for grinding.
bone_facts.Left_second_upper_premolar_tooth: The tooth between the first premolar and first molar in the upper jaw.
bone_facts.Left_upper_central_incisor_tooth: The prominent front tooth in the upper jaw, used for slicing food. It is the widest of all incisors.
bone_facts.Left_upper_lateral_incisor_tooth: The tooth next to the central incisor in the upper jaw, known for its variability in shape.
bone_facts.Left_upper_canine_tooth: The long, pointed tooth in the upper jaw, critical for tearing food and guiding the bite.
bone_facts.Right_first_lower_molar_tooth: The large grinding tooth in the back of the right lower jaw.
bone_facts.Right_first_lower_premolar_tooth: The transitional tooth on the right side of the lower jaw.
bone_facts.Right_second_lower_molar_tooth: The second large grinding tooth in the right lower jaw.
bone_facts.Right_second_lower_premolar_tooth: The premolar on the right side of the lower jaw used for grinding.
bone_facts.Right_lower_central_incisor_tooth: The front cutting tooth on the right side of the lower jaw.
bone_facts.Right_lower_lateral_incisor_tooth: The cutting tooth next to the midline on the right side of the lower jaw.
bone_facts.Right_lower_canine_tooth: The pointed tearing tooth on the right side of the lower jaw.
bone_facts.Right_second_upper_molar_tooth: The second molar on the right side of the upper jaw, used for grinding.
bone_facts.Right_first_upper_molar_tooth: The first large grinding tooth on the right side of the upper jaw.
bone_facts.Right_first_upper_premolar_tooth: The first bicuspid on the right side of the upper jaw.
bone_facts.Right_second_upper_premolar_tooth: The second bicuspid on the right side of the upper jaw.
bone_facts.Right_upper_central_incisor_tooth: The large front tooth on the right side of the upper jaw.
bone_facts.Right_upper_lateral_incisor_tooth: The cutting tooth next to the central incisor on the right side of the upper jaw.
bone_facts.Sesamoid_bone_of_right_foot: A small bone embedded within a tendon in the right foot, most commonly found near the big toe joint, which helps reduce friction.
